John MacArthur’s career journey is characterized by a steady progression of ministry and leadership roles. He began his ministry as a young pastor, later establishing a prominent church, and eventually extending his influence through various platforms.

  • 1969:He was ordained as a pastor at Grace Community Church, solidifying his role as a spiritual leader.
  • 1970s:During this decade, MacArthur established the “Grace to You” ministry, a platform dedicated to disseminating his teachings through radio broadcasts, television programs, and publications.
  • 1980s:MacArthur’s influence grew significantly as he published several books, including “The MacArthur Study Bible” and “The Gospel According to Jesus,” which became popular resources for Bible study and theological exploration.
  • 1990s:He continued to expand his ministry through the establishment of the Master’s College and Seminary, an institution dedicated to providing theological education rooted in his beliefs.
  • 2000s:MacArthur’s impact extended further with the launch of “The MacArthur Daily Bible,” a devotional resource that reached a wide audience. He also became a prominent voice in the contemporary evangelical movement, known for his conservative theological stance.

“The Bible is the inspired and infallible Word of God, and it is the sole authority for faith and practice.”

  • Unconditional Election:This doctrine posits that God chooses individuals for salvation before they are born, based on His sovereign will, not on any merit or worthiness on their part.
  • Limited Atonement:This doctrine suggests that Christ’s death on the cross was specifically for the elect, those chosen by God for salvation, not for all humanity.
